data.text: Contents
Introduction

Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (hereinafter referred to as The Trust) is committed to meeting its responsibilities under the Health and Safety at Work etc. Act 1974 (HSWA) and all associated legislation to ensure, as far as reasonably practicable, the health, safety and welfare of all employees and others who may be affected by its undertakings.

The Trust recognises the importance of providing safe working environments, so to ensure as far as reasonably practicable that the working areas are safe, scheduled inspections will be conducted by the Health and Safety Department.

The inspection regimes as laid out in this policy aim to ensure the workplace is being reviewed at least quarterly be staff themselves and annually by the Health and Safety Team. The annual Health and Safety Team led inspections includes Wards, Offices, Compounds, General Work areas Engineering and roof spaces, Internal and External Public areas and Ad hoc inspection following concerns raised by stakeholders.

Department(s) within the hospital not managed by NHS staff will be inspected by the Health and Safety team on an annual basis, there will not be an expectation for them to complete quarterly inspections.
Scope
This document applies to all employees of the Trust in either capacity of the inspector or staff of the area being inspected:
Ensure all staff are aware of their duties laid out in this policy
To highlight actions that need to be carried out to assist with fulfilling the duties under the legislation requirements
NHS Constitution

The Trust is committed to designing and implementing services, policies and measures that meet the diverse needs of its population and workforce, ensuring that no individual or group is disadvantaged.
2.2.1  This policy supports the NHS Constitution as follows:

The Trust aspires to the highest standards of excellence and professionalism in the provision of high-quality care that is safe, effective and focused on patient experience; in the planning and delivery of the clinical and other services it provides; in the people it employs and the education, training and development they receive; in the leadership and management of its organisations; and through its commitment to innovation and to the promotion and conduct of research to improve the current and future health and care of the population.
Definitions

table_items.text: Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust
“workplace” means, any premises or part of premises which are not domestic premises and are made available to any person as a place of work”

The process carried which involves assessing relevant documents held within a particular work area, interviewing people and observing site conditions, standards and practices where work activities are carried out. Its purpose is to secure compliance with legal requirements for which HSE (Health and Safety Executive) is the enforcing authority and to promote improving standards of health and safety within the organisation.

Process for identifying causes and effects of potential situations, tasks or processes that could cause harm or injury to ensure that proportionate precautions via control measures have been put into place to prevent harm or injury

Having due regard for advancing equality involves: Removing or minimising disadvantages suffered by people due to their protected characteristics. Taking steps to meet the needs of people from protected groups where these are different from the needs of other people. Encouraging people from protected groups to participate in public life or in other activities where their participation is disproportionately low.
An individual with the responsibility for Health and Safety arrangements at the site/area being inspected
A source of potential harm or a situation with a potential to cause loss
The likelihood, of something occurring that, could cause harm or a loss
Something which is below an acceptable standard or is faulty

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
The Trust Board and Executive Teams
Trust Board have overall responsibility for the health, safety and welfare of all staff, service users, visitors and others within all Trust premises.
Members of the Executive Management Team have full responsibility for the health, safety and welfare of all staff, visitors and others within the wards, offices etc. under their specific management.
All Directors have a corporate responsibility to promote a responsible approach in health and safety in the Trust.
MSE Health and Safety Management Group
To receive compliance summary reports from audits and inspections to gain assurance that shortfalls are being addressed.
To receive action plans from those areas where there are shortfalls.
To request follow up action if shortfalls are not addressed.
Health and Safety Forums
Each hospital will host its own Health and Safety Forum to highlight local issues, unique to each site.
Where possible resolve local issues, address any local issues
Where resolution cannot be made, escalate to the MSE Health and Safety Management Group
Chief Executive

While ultimate responsibility is vested in the Trust Board, executive responsibility is delegated to the Managing Director for managing health and safety, including compliance with relevant legislation and Trust policies.
The Chief Executive's overall duty is to ensure the Trust complies with its statutory obligations concerning the Health and Safety at Work etc. Act 1974 and associated legislation
To delegate responsibility for monitoring compliance to Divisional Directors and Senior Managers
To ensure that suitable resources are made available to ensure the health safety and welfare of all employees and others who may be affected by its undertaking
Senior Director of Estates and Facilities
Have delegated responsibility for monitoring and reviewing health and safety in the Trust.
Inform the Trust of health and safety matters regularly and ensure adequate resources are made available to provide and maintain the necessary standards of health and safety in the Trust.
Ensures the Trust complies with this policy by meeting health and safety requirements.
Ensures adequate resources, information, consultation and training are in place and achieves compliance.
Directors / Heads of Clinical Services and including Speciality Services
Locality Directors will bring this policy to the attention of all their staff, including new and temporary staff, and the management team and ensure that it is adhered to at all times.
Ensure quarterly inspections are completed promptly
All major findings are closely tracked and reported to the Health and Safety Team and reported at the appropriate local Health and Safety Forum's
Ensure competent Staff under your control are chosen and appropriately trained and given suitable time to complete the quarterly inspection.
Ensure that the process is monitored and adequate support is provided for line managers to ensure that their responsibilities are met.
Ensure arrangements that implement this policy are devised and reviewed.
Play a key leadership role in developing and sustaining a pro-active culture, personal and professional responsibility for health and safety issues.
Clinical Ward Managers, Clinical staff and Office Managers responsibilities:
Ensure that this policy is implemented within the building area of their responsibility.
Investigate all adverse incidents and near misses and take appropriate action.
Conduct quarterly inspections of the workplace to ensure that their area of the building remains in a safe condition.
Nominate a deputy to carry out the inspection should you be unable to carry out your inspection.

Inspections should be made with the co-operation of any accredited health and safety representatives or workplace reps and may be either part of a wider safety inspection. In all cases, written records of these inspections must be kept.

Any major non-conformity must be reported immediately, if there is an imminent threat of injury. Steps to isolate or prevent access to the room/equipment may be necessary. It should also be reported as an urgent job request to resolve the issue or make safe.

Co-operate with the Health and Safety team to allow them to discharge their duties of inspection. For Clinical areas, the Health and Safety team will try to ensure their inspections are timed so they do not have a significant impact on the care of patients, i.e. during meal times or Doctors round etc.
Play a key management role in developing and sustaining a proactive culture, personal and professional responsibility for health and safety issues in their control.
Manual Handling Department
Will be consulted in the development of the inspection criteria recorded on the Health and Safety Inspections
Working within the Health and Safety team to resolve any manual handling issues raised during any inspection.
Health and Safety Department duties:
Record/Schedule Inspections to cover as many areas as practicable.
To schedule inspections at such times staff can interact with members of the inspection team, as to make the inspection meaningful
In sensitive areas, the Health and Safety Team may give 1 weeks' notice of inspection and arrange a time and date for these inspections, otherwise unannounced inspections are the normal course.
Maintain records of inspections and be able to upwardly inform senior management on the status of compliance and progress of inspections against agreed schedule.
To provide advice to managers and members of staff in matters relating to conducting inspections or help to deal with remedial actions arising for inspections.
To review the effectiveness of this policy and amending as appropriate.
To deliver suitable training of staff members to a standard that they will be able to complete their quarterly inspection as directed in this policy.

Develop and publish suitable forms that staff and Health and Safety team can use to aid the recording of inspections. Obtain feedback from the competent persons on the continued suitability of the forms used, and amend, only, after further feedback for fellow Health and Safety team members are gained
Information Technology (IT) Department
Scrutinise all requests for hardware purchases.
Provide suitable IT equipment.
All Employees have a responsibility to:
Take action to address hazards in their working areas.
To report any incidents or accidents by completing an electronic incident reporting form via DATIX.
Inspection formats

There are currently several types of inspections undertaken. Quarterly inspections completed by a responsible person in the ward/office or Department, the rest completed by the Health and Safety Team at various frequencies.
5.1.2 Each inspection will start with a review of the action points from the previous inspection. Any unresolved issues will be mentioned in the relevant section of the new report.
5.1.3 The inspection will involve:
Inspections will be more substantial than work equipment and environmental check
Inspections will assess control measures to ensure they are effective, suitable and, proportionate to the risks.
A “walk through” inspection of the department/area
General discussion between the manager(s) and safety representative(s)
Signage and documentation checks
Inspection frequency
The frequency of inspections will be risk based, whereby higher risk areas/ department are monitored more frequently than low risk areas/offices/departments.
5.2.1  These include:

Non-Engineering spaces, clinical departments, Offices, Charity Shops, Mobile screening units etc. these will be inspected over an 18-month period, with the higher risk areas inspected at least annually.
Engineering Spaces Annually
External Public and External Hospital Areas. Twice a year, once in the summer and once in the winter to capture seasonal changes.
Quarterly Ward Inspection
Additional inspections may be necessary where there has been a substantial change to the working environment since the previous inspection but before
the next annual inspection is due). A rolling programme of annual inspections will be prepared by the Health and Safety Team.
Ad hoc inspections following concerns raised by stakeholders.
In addition, ad hoc visits may be undertaken by senior managers or specialist advisors.
Annual scheduled health and safety inspections of wards and departments by the health and safety team
5.3.1 Health and Safety inspections of wards/departments using MSE approved inspection template will be carried out annually by the Health and Safety Team.

5.3.2 Managers or a deputy will be present at the time of the inspection as there may be issues raised that require immediate attention. There may also be questions on the inspection that need to be answered by the manager.
5.3.3 The inspection will then be recorded and a percentage score generated, this and any unresolved issues can be reported at local Forums or MSE Health and Safety Management Group Meeting.
5.3.4 The Inspection Audit Record will use a scoring system with 100% result requiring no action.
5.3.5 Findings will be risk rated Low, Medium, High and actions required will be prioritised for completion according to the risk rating.

table_items.text: High: Action should be taken to resolve the issue/s within Max. 1 month
Medium: Action should be taken to resolve the issue/s within 3 Months
Low: Action should be taken to resolve the issue within 6 months

data.text: 5.3.6 The Risk Rating will be shared with the Ward and Department Manager. Ward and Department Managers will act on the findings and ensure that all necessary actions are undertaken and completed in line with the hazard risk and predetermined completion date.

5.3.7 Ward and Department Managers will inform the Health and Safety Team when all of the actions identified have been completed, or if there any issues which postpone the completion of actions. Completed Inspection Checklists will be retained for audit purposes.
5.3.8 A hard copy should be stored in the areas risk folders (hard copy or electronic) and a central copy held by the Health and Safety team.
Annual engineering spaces inspections

On an ongoing annual basis, all engineering spaces will be inspected by the Health and Safety Team. Main plant rooms will be inspected and a Risk Assessment will be produced outlining the probable hazards within the room. The assessments will be displayed at the entrance to the room.
Bi-annual health and safety inspections of external and public areas by the health and safety team

5.5.1 Health and Safety inspections of communal areas both external and internal will be carried out bi- annually by the Health and Safety Teams at each Hospital. The findings will be logged on a health and safety (communal areas) spread sheet and will be risk rated Low, Medium, High risk and prioritised according to the risk rating.
5.5.2 Any repairs required will be logged with the Facilities Helpdesk.
5.5.3 Any significant repairs logged will be monitored by the Health and Safety team until completion.
5.5.4 A follow up inspection will be conducted to ensure that the repair has been completed, with time scale determined by the risk rating.
Quarterly ward/department inspection by local competent person
Health and Safety inspections of wards, departments using MSE approved inspection template will be carried out quarterly by the department lead or nominated individual.
Health and safety audit

Ad hoc Audits will be conducted, usually by the Business Development Unit and are measured against recognised ISO Standards 9001, 14001 and, 45001. The Health and Safety Team will support the BDU team where required in undertaking these.
The Health and Safety Team may adopt the general principles of ISO 45001 standard and Audit high risk activities.
Inspection team
The inspection team will comprise of the relevant local manager/ designated person.
Others from the list below should be notified of the inspection in order to allow them to provide information to the inspection team prior to the inspection and/or participate during the inspection:
Staff Side safety representative
Clinical representative(s)
Local Health and Safety Champion / Link Worker
Estates representative
Ideally the team will include a representative from each of the above mentioned personnel; however, the inspection should not be cancelled because they are not available.
Areas to be inspected
Each Local Health and Safety Team will ensure that a list of areas are prepared to include the name and contact information of the local manager / designated person for each site/service area listed.
The list will include premises in which staff are based or co-located (e.g. community hospitals used by mental health staff or social services premises used by community staff).
Records and actions
Quarterly Inspections

The manager or designated person will be responsible for recording the outcomes of the inspection using the standard Quarterly Health and Safety Inspection Checklist; this provides an Action Plan template which includes key issues, recommendations, agreed actions, priorities and timescales.

During the inspection, responsibility for each action will be agreed, risk rated and recorded on the inspection report. Actions must be implemented or delegated by the relevant manager/designated person in accordance with their agreed priority.

Some remedial actions may be taken during the inspection and the status of action taken will be recorded on the inspection checklist i.e. detail of action taken / complete / etc. If any health and safety issues are identified during an inspection of premises in which Trust staff are based or co-located and the Trust is not the Landlord it is the responsibility of the Departments manager to ensure that the responsible manager for the site/premises involved is informed, and an action plan agreed with them.

The manager or designated person, responsible for the quarterly inspections, will send copies of the inspection report to all relevant members of the inspection team and to the Trust Health and Safety Team within 20 working days from the date of the inspection.
Inspections conducted by the Health and Safety team will be sent to the Ward/Area Managers within 7 working days or sooner.
Inspection reports and summary schedules will be retained electronically by the Local Health and Safety Team for a minimum of three years.
Local copies of the inspections must be kept locally within the Health and Safety risk folder or in the desktop files.

If any dispute is raised during the inspection process and agreement can be reached about the inspection of these premises, or about remedial action to be taken on identified hazards, the manager or designated person will consult with the Head of Health and Safety. Concerns must be escalated as appropriate if they cannot be resolved locally.
Urgent actions and issues with wider significance
Where a significant risk has been identified this must be addressed in accordance with Trust's Risk management strategy (MSEPO-20242) and escalated as appropriate.
Training requirements
Training is provided to the user relating to general health and safety in the working environment.

Where bespoke software packages are used then specific, targeted training must be provided to the users. This means that the training should be purchased along with the software package. Provision must be made for any further training to be accessed.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Health and Safety Management Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local Policy and procedure guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document
control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Health and Safety Management Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
